newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Cyprus, UN protest Turkish flyovers.
newsitem.headline: Cyprus, UN protest Turkish flyovers.

text.p: Cyprus and U.N. peacekeepers protested on Friday after Turkish warplanes twice swept low over Nicoasia on the 13th anniversary of the creation of the breakaway Turkish Cypriot state.

Acting Cypriot President Spyros Kyprianou summoned ambassadors of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council to protest an hour after the Turkish F-16s flew over the centre of the divided capital.
Six planes painted red and white roared over twice during a midday military parade in the Turkish-held area of the island on the 13th anniversary of the establishment of the Turkish Cypriot state.

"We have protested these overflights to the Turkish army," U.N. spokesman Waldemar Rokoszewski told Reuters, adding that the planes flew very close to a U.N.-controlled buffer zone dividing the island.

Cyprus has been divided since Turkey invaded its northern third in 1974 in response to a short-lived Greek Cypriot coup engineered by the military ruling Greece at the time. The Turkish Cypriot state is recognised only by Turkey.

Hundreds of Greek Cypriot students and refugees gathered in a Nicosia square to condemn the breakaway state. More than 500 Greek Cypriot police in riot gear watched and blocked roads with barbed wire to prevent students from demonstrating at the ceasefire line.
